title: What is the relationship between optics, gender and subjectivity in medieval love poetry according to Dana E. Stewart's "The arrow of love"?
first_phrase: In the previous part of the text, various studies and observations regarding the influence of emotions on visual perception and communication were presented. Dana E. Stewart's "The arrow of love: optics, gender and subjectivity in medieval love poetry" was referenced to show how certain beliefs influenced medieval society's perception of female menstruation. The text also touched upon infants' ability to respond to a range of facial expressions, including fear and anger. In this last part, references to Michael Argyle's "Bodily Communication" and Stuart Hameroff's work on gamma waves and telepathy are made. It also discusses how the activation of certain facial muscles is necessary for mastication and how children use emotional cues to determine appropriate behavior in ambiguous situations.
